SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

A TEXT OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON GATHERING THE INFORMATION

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer. You do not have to worry about blank spaces, just fill in where necessary.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether or not they were born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did They Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark next to it.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer clothing, sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A LIST OF MATERIALS RELATING TO THE HISTORY OF SASKATCHEWAN, 1870-1920

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada for more than ten years will have experienced all aspects of pioneer life. However, there are certain common experiences which are shared by most pioneers.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada for at least ten years and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer period. It is not necessary to answer every question; only those which apply to your own experience need be answered.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 outlines "Pioneer Days: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" It is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, please do so, and one will be sent to you.

All questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer homestead and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHITECTS' QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: John Bates Dickey

2. Your address: Langham, Sask.

3. Date: April 7, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Middle Musquodoboit, Halifax, Nova Scotia

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: George Scott Dickey, farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 16, 1892

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

New Providence, P.E.I., N.S.A. from 1891 to 1892.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child").

Twenty-one

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My brother-in-law had moved to the West in 1882 and he was looking for me to come and work for him in a trade raising cattle.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

Handwritten note: Through friends.

1. Your full name: John B. Dickey
2. Your address: Langham, Sask.
3. Date: April 7, 1922
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Macdonald, Quebec, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   George Scott Dickey, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   April 16, 1892
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Qu'Appelle, Sask., 1891-1892
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.)
   Twenty-one
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My brothers and I came to the West to make our living on farms.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or Government Information?)
    Through friends
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My relatives thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train to Edmonton via the mail train and then by horse and buggy.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the trail, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences)

I remember meeting a family who had just arrived from Europe. They had traveled all the way by train and then by horse and buggy. They were very friendly and invited us to stay at their homestead. We ended up spending several days with them before continuing our journey.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Papagreen

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

On Papagreen

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working in local places.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My relatives were very pleased. They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family), friends or other group?

I traveled alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the trip, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

I met a friendly Indian who helped me find my way. I also met a kind-hearted man who gave me directions when I got lost.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Peyton

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

De Puyer

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How about you now?

Working in local places.
